reviewText:
I'd have to say, if you're interested in this, do not buy it, at least not now.

Bought it a while ago for my son and I to play, after he was watching a let's play of it. Seemed like a goofy game to mess around with.
It is, actually.
For maybe a round or two.
When we first got it, it had issues, but hey, it's early access, right? Well, as each update came out, it seemed like there were more and more issues. Weird lag, objects not working, getting stuck, random people joining our password protected custom game, etc.
Then, out of nowhere, it's 'released'. I'm sorry, but this game is NOT ready for release.
Not sure where to begin.
How about performance? Pretty abysmal. Can be running smooth, but then the framerate just plummets, mouse movement is all jerky, and it just feels rough.
Graphics-Quite poor. I'm not one to judge a game by it's graphics by any means, but overall, the game just looks bad. Looks like the devs just slapped it together and called it good. Character models are atrocious (hats and glasses are humorous though), textures are all over the place. Some look fine, but others don't make any sense. Go outside and look at the achievement room. The room is flat, but the 'bricks' taper off. Good example of it being slapped together.
Controls-Serviceable I suppose, although picking up items and using them is a major chore.
Balance-absolutely ridiculous. It's not a matter of who is going to win? The baby or the daddy? It's a matter of if the baby dies in one minute or two. The daddy has only a couple things he can do to stave off the baby's death, but there are sooo many options for the baby to off itself, it quickly turns into a race to see just how fast the baby can kill itself, especially with warping through vents.
Idea/concept-brilliant. Actually a really good idea for a game, but there are so many issues right now, I'd stay away. We'll probably keep playing it off and on for a while to see if things improve, but it's quickly becoming tiresome.
One thing I forgot about, and just remembered. The soundtrack. One of the most annoying and grating soundtracks I've ever heard.

Early Access Review

Who's your daddy is a really fun idea for a game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3r8Gq3-vH2Q
Although there are a few strange-looking animations and limited exploration in the current early access build, this is pretty promising. I've never found any glitches, and the main mechanics for the game are already in place and hilarious.

The game is simple, one player is a suicidal baby, trying to find any means of ending its life. Where the other player is the panic-stricken dad trying to keep the baby safe until mum comes home.
Every time a round starts, object locations are randomized, allowing for some pretty good replay value. The baby can end its existence in a multitude of ways. E.g: Stick a fork in an outlet, drown itself in the sink or cook itself in the oven.
As the dad, you have the ability to take objects out of the baby's hands directly and put them on higher up counters out of its reach. You may also lock certain cabinets if you find a padlock, or turn off faucets.

At the moment, the game is relatively well balanced, although I feel like the dad might be a bit overpowered if the player chooses to follow the baby constantly.
Right now, you can complete a chore by throwing all of the baby's toys into the toybox, and then obtain a random powerup like the ability to see items through walls or be invisible to the baby.
This chore is completely optional though.
I feel like the chore(s) should be mandatory, so they must be complete as well as the baby survive until mum comes home. It might sound a bit tough for the Dad, but it's the only method I can think of to prevent the dad from just preying on the baby constantly. Besides, he can force pull objects out of the baby's hand. Perhaps the baby could respawn in a random spot instead? Those are just a few suggestions.

Overall, I can't wait until more death opportunities arrive, and more house rooms are created. It's a really funny base for a game, and genuinely well executed. (Perhaps also a game mode where the baby needs to run away from the dad, because it can be picked up and thrown into the toilet or oven?) Did I say that out loud?

Recommended!

reviewText:
NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS OF THE EARLY ACCESS VERSION AND IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE AS VERSIONS ARE RELEASED.

(Written as of....Alpha V0.3.0. Can't wait for the update this friday!)

The game right now is fun but has issues. The gameplay is rather simple. One player is a baby who must die before time runs out (I think it's 4 minutes.) while the dad must keep him safe.

Now while the gameplay has evolved over the versions (Pills used to heal baby too and were infinite.) the game has some serious balance issues. I was able to play for about an hour as baby (I'd leave and make a new lobby each time so I'm always baby.) and was able to win every time, often before the first 30 seconds. Forks spawn near the crib and you can easily jump up, grab it, and use it on an outlet to die instantanously. If a hammer is on the TV stand you can smash the coffee table and eat the glass to die quick too.

Daddy gameplay is fun too but it seems very easy to shut baby away from harm if you know where to look. (Put knives and forks on sofa, etc.)

The main ways to die as Baby are either electrocution by outlet or poisoning (Glass works the fastest.) drowning or cooking yourself in the oven takes too long and can be easily stopped by Daddy, which should be made faster.

The game also has technical flaws. Often the countdown before a match starts glitches and I have to alt F4, but it's rare. (I get it often enough I'll complain on the review though.)

The house has alot of rooms locked (WIP stuff not added yet.) so I can't say for the finished state yet. It might be more balanced and fair if more rooms are involved (there's literally no reason to go upstairs currently. Nothing dangerous spawns up there aside from power outlets you can use to zap yourself, and there's no falling damage. There is a funny ♥♥♥♥♥ hidden in the bedroom though.) but it's hard to say. I know the next update adds ventilation shafts and more chores Daddy can do.

Speaking of the chores, they're not easy. Putting all toys away takes a good deal of time and by the time you're distracted doing that Baby often offs himself. Finding the smoke detector battery is iffy. Sometimes I swear it doesn't spawn at all, which might be a glitch. (Or maybe I'm not looking hard enough.) The next update adds more chores and daddy powers. Doing the chores gives you daddy powers like being able to see Baby through walls or see objects through walls, or be invisible to baby.

Now for the main question, is it worth the 5 dollars? Honestly, yes. The game has serious potential to be amazing with more features which are coming soon.


EDIT: It's been a long time since I came back, but here I am! This section was written after the outside update was released.

The game was expanded. Baby's crib was moved to the bedroom, then it was moved to the baby's room which was previously locked upstairs.

New rooms include a garage where you can blow yourself up with a car or set yourself on fire with gasoline, an office room upstairs, a shower upstairs with chemicals for baby to drink or burn in the shower, a laundry room with a washer and dryer for baby to die in, and an outside area with a pool.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt a glance, Who's Your Daddy might look like just another one of those garbage games that somehow passed through greenlight - but unlike most of those games, Who's Your Daddy is actually surprisingly fun. The game's concept is fairly simple, in which one player plays as a baby and tries to kill themself using a variety of household objects, while the other player controls a dad trying to protect the baby, providing a shockingly realistic portrayal of actual parenthood. There are a variety of ways for the baby to kill themself, like eating batteries or dropping a toaster in the sink, giving the game replayability by challenging yourself to kill yourself in creative ways. The dad gets various objects to try to protect the baby, like a tool to lock drawers and a baby grabbing handle to temporarily pick up the baby, and can also do chores around the house to get powerups like Dad Bod, which allows you to carry heavier things. The game is only in alpha right now, but the developer seems to be fairly diligent in adding regular updates that add new features and ways to die, and at five dollars per copy I think it's a pretty good game to get together with a friend and have a few hours of laughter.

reviewText:
♥ It isn't hard to run.

This is something I deeply appreciate because though my computer is on the higher end, it can struggle to run games like Minecraft or TF2, and I like to not hear my computer wheezing and coughing like it's going to die.

I'm not sure how it would run on a laptop but I'd imagine it would be fine on a lower end or low graphics computer! : D

♥ I like how you change roles.

There are some games that I find boring when you're stuck playing as one character or the other for the entire game time. However with Who's Your Daddy, you switch places each round, playing as the baby or the daddy then vice versa. This way it helps to mix up the game play!

♥ Playing this was so entertaining.

During the short time that I played, it cracked me up to no end. I love how dark the game is yet how amusing it is at the same time. I appreciate games that know not to take themselves seriously. For sure a must play if you're having a bad day or want to have some silly fun with a friend.

✘ The number one problem with this game is my motion sickness.

When I played with my friend, I felt horrendously sick and have been unable to play it again. This is far from the dev team's fault however I thought to include it in my review for others who suffer from motion sickness. If you do, be warned that this game may be hard on you.

✘ The graphics could be better.

It doesn't matter that much to me - it's a game to have fun in, not a game to be impressed by the graphics, or spend time staring at how realistic the floor looks. I do think that the baby looks terribly creepy...I'll let him get into the cleaner, LOL. Of course I'm not serious about that.

✘ It isn't a game to play with your friend if you aren't going to use your mics.

I played this game while skyping with my friend. If you were going to spend time texting/messaging, there would be no way - you either play the game or chat! By using your mics, you can still chat and have fun.

Overall I absolutely suggest this game for people looking for fun co-op/multiplayer games!!

I have played this game quite a bit, even if just currently 2.2 hours, I've killed myself in every way possible as the baby and would proclaim that I can be a great dad who can block his baby from killing him/herself, equally so - I can kill myself anytime as the baby. One could say babies capabilities to kill itself is OP. Sometimes it's true, sometimes not.

Review: The game is 1v1, Online-only Dad Vs Suicidal Baby. Items randomly position themselves everytime in select locations that are meant for the dad, or for the baby. Things ranging from a Padlock for the dad to lock cupboards so the baby has harder time accessing poison and dangerous objects, but also things like the Baby Key which can unlock the cupboards if found and used. Other items may range from Fruit, or meat in the fridge which can heal the baby if 'wounded'.

The point is to keep your baby alive obviously, or to die if you're the baby, it's fun whether with a stranger or with a friend.

I make Let's Plays in my spare time and I've currently made 3 videos. The first is my first experience with the game and the troubles of settling in. The 2nd was me showing off my 'Skill as the Dad' and the 3rd and most recent at the time of writing this was me being the most miserable little ♥♥♥♥ as possible as a baby. A link to the gameplay videos will be below for those who wish to help me and view gameplay to learn the ins and outs of the game! :>

My only wish is that the game of course, continues to be updated, not only will there be new rooms in the future and fixes to the game already, but I hope later from there we'll receive different areas like Outside, a Park, a backyard, or a new house layout to continue expanding the game. :D

My only Cons about the game is that after 1-3 hours, you may already be done the game. I don't see this being a Long-term issue though as long as new layouts, levels, obtsacles and items continue being made though. I'd love to see more ideas/games like this in the future to appease my sadistic nature :>

reviewText:
Who's Your Daddy is a game where you can play one of two characters and follow their story.

Character 1: Daddy
Daddy's goal in life is to become one of the greatest Daddy's mankind has ever known. In order to do so he must stop his suicidal baby (gender unknown) from killing itself. His journey is that of true hardship. He must keep his dimented baby from killing itself until 4:00 PM, which is when Mom comes home. We know nothing about Mom, but we can assume that she is the mastermind behind this entire scenario.

Character 2: Baby
Baby's goal is to destroy itself by any means necesary. Any household appliance is just a new way for Baby to kill itself. However, Daddy is going to be howling over him like a police officer howls over an African American male walking down the street. There's a time limit. Mom comes home at 4:00 PM, so Baby must kill itself before that time using anything it can.

tl; dr:
If you're Daddy, protect the Baby.
If you're Baby, ♥♥♥♥ing KILL YOURSELF.

Overall I give this game 4:00 PM/10 would light babies on fire again.

Who's Your Daddy is a game where you either take the role of a father or son. The son tries to kill himself in many different horribly scarring ways. The father tries to stop him. I really shouldn't care, it's a game about a suicidal infant who can douse himself in gasoline and light himself on fire.
But still, there are some issues with that. (Also, FIX THE DAD'S HAIR)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is strange, but I guess I'll try to write a review on it...

The Graphics

While not exactly 'pretty' to look at, the graphics of this game fit the style of this game well. The game is goofy and funny, and so are the graphics. They are your average mediocre (did I misspell that? :P) game graphics, but in this game, they are fine. The baby looks like a idiot. PERFECT. 8.5/10

The Gameplay

The real point of any game, the gameplay.  It is...strange, but it is really fun. The fact 0.9.5 introduced like 5 new rooms and new items is AWESOME, as well as the relocation of the baby, so the dad can't clearly see the baby immediately. Yes, he can use the baby cam by turning on the TV, but it is not as clear as how it used to be at seeing the baby from the start. However, the baby is never at an advantage from the start: there are many items the father can use to protect the baby. By far my favorite death, though....it MUST be the exploding toaster. Look it up :P. 9.3/10

The Price
Five bucks.









YUS10/10

The Story

While it doesen't matter much, you are a clueless father who is trying to protect your kid. 9.5/10 for realism.

The Freak-ing GLITCHES

AGH! This is the only problem with the game. Tons of things are glitched, and otehrs are just broken. I'm sorry...5.5/10

The OTHER

That's really it.

The Conclusion

A really great game, but it is so glitchy. Please fix these bugs, and I will probably consider this game a better one than it is. All in all, I give this game: 8.5/10.

Genre: First-person Multiplayer
Developer: Joe Williams
Publisher: Joe Williams
Copy supplied by Steam

Who's Your Daddy is a first-person multiplayer game developed and published by Joe Williams.

GRAPHICSPowered by the Unity engine, the house and its furniture don't look half bad. But the models of the dad and the baby are nightmare inducing: lifeless animations, creepy faces and an exorcist-like crouching movement for the dad make you wonder if it was all intentional just to make the game more fun. If that was the developer's intention, he succeeded.

GAMEPLAYRight now there are only one map and game mode. There are two players: a baby who's trying to kill himself, and his dad who must keep that from happening. As the baby, you have a moltitude of ways to suicide: drowning in the bathtub, drinking bleach to poison yourself, putting a fork in an electricity socket, cooking yourself in the oven... As the dad, you can pick up the object the kid is carrying, give him food and pills to heal him, use items to lock cabinets... There are many possibilities for both characters, and the randomly generated position of the objects makes every round fun and entertaining. However, the lack of variety starts to settle in after 30 minutes of playtime.

CHALLENGEIt all depends on the players: a good baby knows the fastest ways to die, and a good dad knows which objects to use and what to do to avoid your son's death.

SOUNDThe sound effects are pretty standard, but the music is really, REALLY annoying, with the same cheerful tune going on an endless loop for the entire time!!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At the time of writing this, I've played around an hour of Who's Your Daddy. The game is... interesting, to say the least.


PROs -
You get to say 'Who's your daddy?!' over and over to your partner / child.
Two characters to play as - the baby and the daddy.
Two ways to play - be a daddy with a big family, or a daddy with but one baby.
Daddy is strong, and can pick up chairs and stuff, to keep the baby from dying.
A full house, for the baby to play in.
The ability to moniter the baby's health, in case they drink window cleaner, or eat batteries.
Replay-ability. It's set in stone that one day I will return to this game and have some more daddy / baby action.
Many ways for the baby to die, and many ways for daddy to stop it from happening.
Loads of items, for both baby and daddy to use to their advantage
Random places for things to spawn - you cannot memorise the map, because sometimes items move from one place to another.

CONs -
There is an object named 'Strange Rubber Object'. 'Nuff said.
Daddy's crouch position just puts his torso inside his legs, and makes him smaller.
Daddy cannot taser the baby???!!11
Only one house, and only one daddy ;)))))



I can imagine the game will get even better after it fully releases, but so far, I r8 8/8 m8.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At the time of writing this, I've played around an hour of Who's Your Daddy. The game is... interesting, to say the least.


PROs -
You get to say 'Who's your daddy?!' over and over to your partner / child.
Two characters to play as - the baby and the daddy.
Two ways to play - be a daddy with a big family, or a daddy with but one baby.
Daddy is strong, and can pick up chairs and stuff, to keep the baby from dying.
A full house, for the baby to play in.
The ability to moniter the baby's health, in case they drink window cleaner, or eat batteries.
Replay-ability. It's set in stone that one day I will return to this game and have some more daddy / baby action.
Many ways for the baby to die, and many ways for daddy to stop it from happening.
Loads of items, for both baby and daddy to use to their advantage
Random places for things to spawn - you cannot memorise the map, because sometimes items move from one place to another.

CONs -
There is an object named 'Strange Rubber Object'. 'Nuff said.
Daddy's crouch position just puts his torso inside his legs, and makes him smaller.
Daddy cannot taser the baby???!!11
Only one house, and only one daddy ;)))))



I can imagine the game will get even better after it fully releases, but so far, I r8 8/8 m8.

Hm. Do I reccomend this game?
Honestly, yes.

Well, first of all it's a $5.00 game, and it's not finished yet, so sure it may have bad graphics (although I like them) and sure there are some stuff wrong with it, but for $5 and knowing the fact its going to be updated and probably fixed, this game is pretty cool.

You play as the dad or the baby. The baby's job is to kill itself in many different ways around the house. There are going to be different gamemodes so that's not necessarily all you have to do.
The dads job is to stop the baby from killing itself until 4 PM when the mom gets home.
There is many different ways in which you could kill yourself as a baby! Some are easy and require one step. (i.e drinking bleach, eating soap bar, etc.) and some require a couple of steps. (Grab a hammer, break the table/windows and eat the glass, grab a fork or a knife and put it in the outlet, etc)
Another thing I like about this is....
the fact that you can stab your dad, use a laser to make him blind and tazer him. 10/10
But seriously, I do recommend this game if you like goat simulator or just plain fun and funny multiplayer games!

reviewText:
This is a review of the game as it was went it exited early-access:

I still love this game, but unfortunately I can't recommend it to anyone in its current state.\\\\\

It's honestly quite broken at the moment.
A friend and I, who have been following the game for a while, started up a private 'original' game as baby and daddy. The baby won (obviously, since the balance of the game is way off in my opinion, but that's not really a complaint of mine), and we found that there were no options given once the baby won beyond entering spectator mode. Once in spectator mode, the menu could not be entered, and the only way to do anything with the game was exiting.
Additionally, if one waits long enough, the Daddy will actually win, as time keeps going until 4'o'clock.

Numerous physics issues, particularly once you pick up the pool skimmer. That thing knocks furniture everywhere, including dozens of feet into the sky and over the fence. Which is arguably one of the more fun parts of the update, but it does cause a number of issues (such as babies getting stuck behind furniture, and not in a baby-proof way).
Another worth mentioning is the vent in the achievement room causes one to be stuck in the shower head/wall/wherever you come from.

All that said, the new things added in the full release are preeeetty sweet. The yard, the pool, the achievement room and its vent, all dope. I still love this game, I just don't consider it complete yet.

reviewText:
Before I get into the specifics, I want it to be clear that I am reviewing this game while it is still under some heavy construction in terms of bugginess.

This game is definitely worth playing. Conceptually, it is hilarious. It is really easy to be drawn into the competitiveness of trying to kill your baby self in the most hilarious way possible, or trying to stop your babies from dying. Personally, I think Family Gathering mode is best. The more players, the better, in my opinion. It makes the game more competitive and a lot more fun. Unfortunately, as of right now, Family Gathering has come with the most bugs for me and my gamer circle of friends.
